Fig. 3( b) ▸ shows the full k field-of-view comprising many BZs with the Γ- and N-points marked by plus signs and circles, respectively. Recording multiple BZs allows for multiplexing of the observed band features, exploiting the periodicity of the bandstructure in k-space. This leads to an effective enhancement of the intensity (more precisely, to a reduction of the statistical noise) as visible in Figs. 3( c)–3( f) ▸. The sections through a single N-point ( c) and Γ-point ( e) look more diffuse than the sections through five summed N-points ( d) and five Γ-points ( f). In the section through N the outward-dispersing hole pocket ( d) and through Γ the inward-dispersing electron octahedron close to E F, with adjacent local bandgap and hole-type occupied bands below at E B > 1.25 eV ( f), are clearly visible.
